A question for those of you who potty trained full-time. First off, I know every child is different with their own sets of challenges but I am curious as to how long did it take for your child to fully potty train when training full time. I've been training for 4 days now by what I thought was full-time due to bad advice, and prior to reading this great forum, felt as if I had failed miserably at it. I wish I had found this sooner, now I feel as if I've completely confused my child. I will go bare bum and continue through naps and bedtime (using cloth underwear). I'm taking a leap! Comments for Post (8)

What were you doing prior? Do NOT feel bad, there's a lot of myths and bad advice out there about potty training and parenting in general. You're here now and we will support you. It took my dd a week to "get it", a few weeks for minimal accidents but still some (never poop just pee). The pee accidents were always due to laziness or being to busy and running to potty last minute. Stubbornness is the biggest challenge. She never wets the bed.

About 2 months total to have rare pee accidents. I'm talking once a week. Now it's been ages and I can't recall the last accident but I'm sure it could happen out of the blue. She's been trained since before Summer. She's 30 months now. I did a three day method with my two older boys. My oldest took about 8 days to be pee trained, then 6 months for poop (he was older and afraid to sit on the toilet-he fell in and never forgot it) my middle boy took 7 days for pee, and 4 months for poop.

(he was also physically older, but mentally younger-but he also fell in the toilet so again we had to get over a fear). It took about 4 nights with both of them before they stayed dry through the night. After that initial training, there of course were accidents, and little regressions. It's been a year since I pt'ed my middle boy, and I don't remember the last accident. I'm now starting my 18 mo, and because of my driving schedule with my older boys school, there is no way I can be home for three days, so I've been doing it differently. For the past 3 weeks, I've been taking him to the toilet on a schedule, and whenever he asks me. Tomorrow, my husband is taking half the day off, so he can drive my boys to school.

I am going to do bare bum except for naps and bedtime until saturday, then sunday I'm going to put him in underwear. Hopefully he will be to a point where I can drive my boys to school again monday. Thank you ladies for your wonderful feedback. It really feels good to know I've found a great support group who's knowledgeable. My DD is 24 months and met the criteria most give for potty training readiness. I, on the other hand, wasn't but decided to go forth with it because I had read all about not taking advantage of their 'window of opportunity' when presented. I'm a SAHM so I feel as I have no excuse as to why I shouldn't go forth with this.

I was told by many that the best way to PT is to start with pull ups and first do day time then move to night time from there. I was assured not to worry that the night process would take years to master. Well, I don't know about others but I am NOT interested in this being a 3 year commitment. I feel I don't have time for that. I also have a 5 month old that craves as much of my attention at the moment as my 24 month old. Sorry, rant over. What have Ibeen doing?

Not pull ups. I bought plenty of cloth training underwear. We use them during our wake hours. After our 4th day of PT we are at about 45% success rate. I put her back in her diapers for naps and bedtime. When I ask her for her personal preference she always favors her diapers. I don't consent her wishes and this is where I pull out her Tangled panties and she's instantly sold on the idea.

I do feel as she "gets it" because she's improving. Our accidents come from laziness and when absorbed in her favorite shows. So I'm constantly reminding her and we have a lot less tv time than usual. We will be going out of town and staying in a hotel this Saturday so I am going to hold off on taking the plunge into night training and put it off until Sunday night. I feel it's not fair to her to have to train one night and be off the hook the next and then expected to perform the following. But we will go bare bum today! It sounds like you are doing well with her.

Most kids accidents are because they don't want to stop playing to go to the bathroom. Hang in there, and keep it up. But start the night training as soon as you can. I understand wanting to wait until after the trip, but don't wait longer than that! Night training also helps them to not have accidents during the day. At night is when they are exercising their muscles the most, so it will make them better during the day too. I'm super excited, today!

Today has been our first day of bare bum training and....it's working!! I'm ecstatic! She has emptied her bladder 10 times in the potty and has had only one accident which was while jumping on her mini trampoline. She is really proud of herself and cheers herself on. For nap time I felt I had to put her in a diaper as we have family visiting this afternoon. Ugh, I really didn't want to and neither did she. I wish we weren't leaving town this weekend.

And most importantly, I hope this doesn't set us back. I purchased the Gerber training pants. My daughter stays pretty hydrated. She loves water. She is always peeing. She soaks those overnight diapers like you wouldn't believe. There is no way cloth diapers would hold up with out me withholding fluids from her.

I wondered if it was the gerber ones. I've read a ton of reviews online, and watched youtube video reviews on so many different brand and types. I was going to go with kushies, because they are relatively cheap. But I had a few moms on here tell me they are a pain to pull off when wet, like trying to take a wet swimming suit off. I ended up choosing tinkle time trainers. they have pockets in the night ones, so you can add inserts and adjust absorbency. You can either buy the pattern and make them yourself, or since I don't have time to sew, I had the lady who designed them make them for me.

She custom makes them. The draw back is, you have to wait for them to get done. I ordered mine about three days ago, and she is still making my test ones. I'm impatient for them because I'm already potty training, and I hate using pull ups. anyway, I think you should try some other trainers, and get away from diapers/pull ups. That is where I started. She will never learn to go through the night dry, if you keep using diapers, nor will she learn to get up and pee and go back to bed.

It took about a month for night training with me taking her in middle of night to toilet. Plus she peed twice before bed. Eventually she started sleeping through dry or waking me to ask to go. I was able to be at home the entire three days and watch them like a hawk. I've ordered cloth training pants for driving time, and bed time. Who on top of that still nurses pretty frequently. I've never used cloth before, but the circumstances with training my 18 mo are requiring them.

Gerber got awful reviews, they don't even protect kids who have light pees during the day! Amar has many brands listed in her read before posting post. She has also actually tried all those brands, so she can help better than I can if you choose to go this route. I wrote this when my son was learning to use the potty. He is older now and it is mostly a distant memory. I hope you will come away from these articles with a few ideas, some laughter and some hope. Remember this one thing - when it seems like there is no hope, no end to it, know that they will learn it eventually.

Like all the stages kids go through, none of them last for very long. So here we go: I was tired of diapers. That's it. That's the main reason. That and we could use the money. You may be thinking one or two things right now.

Either I am a bad mom for what you think is pushing my son into it too soon or you are where I'm at now and can relate. Either way you are probably right. I have heard potty training requires a lot of patience, but I was unprepared for how much patience is really needed. An unbelievable amount of patience is required for this. You need patience, patience and more patience. Did I mention you need patience? I had read articles and ideas from other parents from all over the Internet and all I really discovered was there are just as many different ways to train your little poop machine as there are people.

It's amazing how many different approaches there are. We are doing a kind of "Boot Camp" type of potty training where we go without diapers at home and use a pull up over underwear when out in case we have an accident. I want to do it this way even though it will take all my time for a few days. I much rather take off work for a few days to master this than drag it out over weeks or even months. Who has the time and patience for that long? I bought some really cute cartoon underwear he loves. You will want to let them pick them out as they will be less inclined to "soil" their favorite cartoon characters.

It's amazing how small these underwear are! Anyway, I think I'm prepared with at ton of rewards, bribes and cleaning supplies on hand. So I decided to take the no-nonsense, don't wait forever to start approach. Though my son is only 2, I feel many parents wait way too long to start. I don't want to wait till when we "have" to as he's starting pre-school. That kind of pressure may be too much for him and me. He has been showing the signs of interest and though he isn't good at all of them I feel he is ready.

Adventures in Potty Training Part 1 This is the first article in a series of our adventures in potty training. Okay, in July, we'd be discussing tons of fun stuff regarding the number 1 toddler challenge: Potty Training . The series will run every Wednesday and the articles will include tips on toilet training, readiness, potty training-on-the-go and resources to help you out. As part of the series and courtesy of sponsor Potty Tots , I have a great giveaway - a complete Potty Training Kit with video, book and charts! There's also a Magic Bowl Potty Training DVD and Book for grabs! Potty Training for Preschool

Many parents go through the panic that happens when they realize that preschool is starting soon and their child is still not potty trained. It is not that uncommon to have this happen to parents. We all forget that the time is coming and that school will be starting. Suddenly, you realize that your child will be starting school and they are still not potty trained yet. This is not a good situation to be in though either. It can be very stressful and nerve racking to realize that your child is starting school and still wearing diapers. Especially since schools will not take children into preschool or kindergarten when they are not potty trained, not to mention that some day cares even have policies against taking children of certain ages in to the school when they are not potty trained as well.

Also, going into daycare and not being potty trained can also mean a higher cost of the child care too. However, you can still get your child potty trained in time for school. There are methods that can be used to have your child potty trained and in plenty of time too. It will take more time on your part, since you will be having to potty train them quicker than normal, however it can still be done and still be an enjoyable experience too. That is why we created this entire section on potty training for pre-school. You will find plenty of helpful tips, tricks and information on how to have your child potty trained in time and make sure you check out Potty Training Tips & Info for all our potty training tips and information. Potty Training Age

Every child potty trains at a different age and there is no right age necessarily as to when to begin potty training. This can be a tough question to answer and really comes down to when your child is ready to potty train more so than their actual age. However, it can be hard to always know when your child is ready to begin potty training or what age to start the process in. Many people have probably told you what they do or what age your child must start potty training . Though this can be helpful, it may not actually be what is right for your child. What your child needs will vary greatly from someone else child and though they are trying to help, you need to do what is best for your family, even when it is different than what someone else has done. We understand this and have created this entire section to cover these questions about age and potty training.

There are many articles to look through that cover the topic and will help you understand what to look for and what to do when potty training , depending on your child's age. This is an exciting time when your child is growing up, becoming aware of themselves more than ever and becoming more independent too. Potty training should be fun and enjoyable for you and your child and it can be when you have all the tools and resources that are needed when you are potty training, make sure you check out our great section: Potty Training Tips & Info. First you will need to get prepared. Check out the post of resources and do some reading on the sites we have listed. Once you feel like you have everything you need to get started this is what we recommend. Your child will do better if not afraid, or if used to the potty.

Whether you are using the potty chair or the toilet, you need to get him/her accustomed to it. Start by letting them check it out fully clothed. I did this with my son by sitting him on the toilet, and he didn't like it. So I spent a day sitting him on the toilet at different times and gave him an m&m while sitting. He learned it wasn't scary to sit while eating. Then I took just his pants off and repeated. Then I took his diaper off and repeated.

By the end of the day he was totally comfortable sitting on the toilet without any treats at all. It only took him one day to go through all the stages. Once I saw he was comfortable with one, I'd move on to the next. Then I spent about 2 weeks taking him to sit on the toilet on a schedule. I was mostly wanting to teach him that we go to the toilet upon waking up, leaving the house, getting home, and before nap/bed time. In addition to trying at these times, he'd ask to go, and I always took him as soon as he asked. Even if we were out to eat, and he was just doing it to get out of his high chair.

I used it as a learning experience that going to the bathroom is expected while eating, and going doesn't get him out of a situation he doesn't like. He went maybe once or twice the entire two weeks. I also made sure to keep his diaper dry. I checked it very frequently and changed it if it was even a little wet. I quickly switched him to pull ups because it was hard to unfasten the diaper for all the practicing we were doing. Plus the pull up had the fading picture if he wetted himself, so it was easier to check him. I showed him the picture and told him he was dry if the picture was still there.

Or wet if it was gone. I also taught him the difference between wet and dry by letting him feel a wet and then dry rag. With my two older boys, I did not do any of this. They were afraid to sit on the toilet, it was a lot harder to jump right in the training without them prepped a little for it. Now that your child is prepped to be trained, you need to choose a method. I have trained three boys now and I just want to say up front that there is a lot of propaganda out there claiming you can have a child totally trained in 3 days or less. This just isn't true.

It takes commitment, and time. We are going to go over two ways to initiate training. Bare bum, and going from diaper to underwear. With my first two boys, I went straight to underwear. If you choose this method, be prepared for a lot of laundry and make sure you have 40-50 pairs of underwear for the first day. My oldest used 40 pairs of underwear in the first day, and close to 30 the second day. We don't realize it, but our kids do little pees often, and we think when their diaper is full they just did a big release.

With my youngest boy, I chose to train him bare bum. When you are ready to start, have your child throw out all diapers/pull ups so they know there is no going back. I gave my kids extra fluid to drink in the morning to give more learning experiences. I never forced them to drink if they didn't want to, I didn't want to make them sick. But I broke out the drinks they don't usually get like juice boxes and such. I do this with and right after breakfast. I tell them the whole time I'm waiting to keep their underwear dry.

This is the perfect time to show them what they need to do with pee and poop, using a doll and a syringe of water for pee, prunes for poop. Give the doll a drink, then have it go potty on the toilet. Have your little one help with the doll. Then when they have their first accident I show them their underwear got wet and take them to sit on the toilet and tell them to put more pee in the toilet. Hopefully you caught them mid stream, or after just a drop or two is in their underwear, but if it is a full release that's ok. The first little while, they most likely won't be able to finish in the toilet because they don't quite know how to control their sphincter muscle. Usually by the end of the first day, they have realized how their body feels and that they need to get to the toilet, but may not be able to get there quite on time.

Continue giving extra fluids at breakfast for the next two days or so to make sure they have lots of opportunities to go and practice. Plan on life stopping for the initial two or three days. You need to be able to watch them like a hawk, and catch every single accident so they know this isn't optional. Remind them several times by asking if they are dry. Praise them if they are dry then tell them to tell you when they need to go. Never ask them if they need to go, the answer will always be no. For Pee bare bum:

I also gave my son extra fluid to drink with this method, but again, only in the morning. Then I had him completely naked for two days. I turned up the heat in my house so he was comfortable. Then I tried to keep him on my wood floors so accidents were easy to wipe clean. Bare bum is easier for the kid to recognize what their body is doing because they can see it coming out, and feel it run down their legs. You want to start putting them in underwear fairly soon because waiting too long will make them have more accidents in underwear because underwear can cause a diaper recall. I figured that the point of bare bum is to get the child to realize what their body is doing and that it needs to be put in the toilet.

So I put him in underwear the 3rd day. I went through 8 pairs of underwear that day. A vast improvement from the 40 pairs I went through with my older two and going straight to underwear. Other than needing to know when to put underwear on, bare bum is pretty much the same as underwear. Watch them closely for the accident, get them to the toilet, then have them help clean their accident. For Poop Training: Poop can take a little longer than pee just because there aren't as many learning experiences with it.

But giving a high fiber diet will help this. Watch them closely for if they start to grunt, or suddenly stop playing and hold still. Get them right to the toilet. Try to distract them while they are sitting so that they can relax and go. Blow bubbles, or read a book to them. For girls you can paint toenails. My son likes me to hand him a toy, then walk away and give him privacy.

If the high fiber diet alone doesn't get them to go every day or every other day, then give them benefiber as well. My kids like the chewable tablets, but some don't. Just put some powder in their drink at breakfast. Miralax is safe for kids, and it is not a laxative. Nap/Night Training: Your child does not have to be dry through the night before you start night training. It is best to start night training either at the same time as day training, or very shortly after.

When your child is not night trained it can lead to accidents during the day because they become desensitized to their feelings of needing to go. Cut all fluids about 2 hours before nap/bed time. Make sure you protect their mattress from accidents. My older boys were still in toddler beds, and my youngest is still in a crib. I bought water proof sheets that do not have a plastic lining. I got three of them, and three sets of sheets so that they could have up to three accidents. Plus the crib mattress itself is waterproof.

So when they had an accident, I just wipe the mattress down with disinfectant wipes, and put a new set of sheets on. Then I do all the washing in the morning. You have spent so much time teaching your child to pee/poop in a diaper, they just don't go in the toilet like flipping a switch. A lot of moms put the potty chair in whatever room they are in, so their kids can get to it faster. Then put them down in their underwear/bare bum depending on the method you chose for training. Remind them to call you if they need to go. Kids usually pee right before waking up, so when you first start to hear them stir, go in and get them to the toilet.

My oldest didn't take naps when I trained him, but my MDS did. I went to him right when I saw him roll over in bed and he would pee in the toilet ( I have a video monitor). With YDS, I have to wake him up from his nap before we go to get his brothers from school, so he has woken up dry for a long time now. If they have an accident in bed, treat it the same way you would an accident on the floor. Calmly remind them pee/poop goes in the toilet. Take them to sit on the toilet to get any more out. Then have them help change the sheets and clean the mess up.

For nights, take them to go at the very beginning of your nighttime routine. Then do bath time, brush teeth, get in pajamas then take them to the toilet one last time before you put them in bed. Keep them in underwear/bare bum. There are a few ways you can train for night. The first way I did with my older two boys. I kept them in their underwear and put them to bed. When they peed themselves it woke them up and they woke me up.

I'd then treat the accident the same way I do during the day and nap. I take them to the toilet to try to get more out. Then I have them help me change the sheets and then I put them back in bed. It only took them 2-3 nights to stop wetting the bed. My oldest figured out to go to the toilet. I'm afraid if he wets the bed or poops the bed, he will suck on it. If you don't have the concern I do with letting them have the accident, go ahead and let them have accidents the first few nights until you know their pattern.

Then go and wake them about 20 minutes before they would wake on their own and take them. This teaches two things, they need to stay dry at night, and it is ok to get up and use the restroom in the middle of the night. Over time, you start to extend the amount of time between trips to the toilet until they are going through the night themselves. Then I thought I'd wake him again at around 3 in the morning. Then one last time at around 5:30 in the morning since he usually wakes up at around 7:30 in the morning. Then go from there depending on if he was wet or dry when waking, and if he goes when waking. The first night I did this, at 9:30 he was wet, and peed more in the toilet.

At 3:30 he was dry, but would not pee. At 5:30 he was dry, but would not pee. At about 6:45 he had diarrhea. The 2nd night I did it, I woke him again at 9:30, and he was dry and would not pee. So I went again at 12:30, and he was dry and again would not pee. Since he was dry at the 3:30 time the night before, I decided to skip this time and went in again at 5:30. He was still dry, and would not pee.

At around 6:30 he called out "mommy, poop" so I went to get him and he hadn't pooped, but peed a small amount. He finished in the toilet. At 7:30 he was dry and he peed again in the toilet. I am doing all this with him still in pull ups. I do not recommend pull ups for training at any time, night or day. Pull ups are diapers. The only reason I am doing it now is to protect his blanket.

I have cloth training pants on order that just aren't here yet. Once I get them, I will switch to using those. Tonight, I plan on taking him at the 9:30 time again, then letting him sleep until about 6. Potty Training can be done at any age, however the older you get them more issues you run into. Some moms prefer doing EC training with babies. Some moms wait for the child to be ready. If you are waiting for your child to be ready, I just want to warn you not to miss that readiness stage.

I did that with my oldest, and he was a lot harder to train. The closer to age two and older you get, the harder it is to potty train because your child is no longer willing. After age 3, it is a habit to go in the diaper, and you fight breaking a habit and the fact that your child is no longer willing. Also when you Potty train keep in mind that every child is different. Potty training is a skill to be taught. It takes time, and every child is different with how much time it takes. If you are dedicated, consistent and follow through, you will be most successful.

How many times did they roll onto their side, only to go back to their back before they figured out how to roll all the way to their tummy? How many times did your baby rock on their hands and knees and fall back down before they finally figured out crawling? How many times did they take a step or two and fall before they figured out how to walk? How long did it take them to prefer walking over crawling? How many times did their food fall off their spoon before they figured out how to hold it level and get it to their mouth? Potty Training is the same as any milestone your child has to learn. They won't be perfect at it right away, and it will take time.

Each child learns at their own pace. Not every child walks right at 12 months, well not every child is potty trained in three days or less. As a matter of a fact, most kids take much longer than three days. If you have the attitude that you want accidents, they will be easier to deal with. Welcome them as learning experiences. Your child can't learn where to put the pee, if they don't first learn how the pee comes out and what it feels like. Then it is like when they learn how to walk, they know how to walk, but they often revert to crawling because it is easier for them to crawl.

We think this is normal and expect it. Well it is the same with potty training. It is a roller coaster they have days where they are completely accident free, then they have days where there are several accidents, and you are wondering what the heck happened! This is all normal. Just be patient, and consistent. The accident days will reduce, and your child will be completely potty trained before you know it! We are here to answer any questions or to just give support.

But if they sit for a while trying to go, they most likely will pee. Most kids pee 3-4 hours after falling asleep, then again 2-3 hours before waking up. Article Body For many parents, a child's emotional readiness for toilet training is the most difficult to recognize-particularly since a child moves in and out of emotional "prime times" and troublesome periods for toilet training throughout early childhood. Emotional issues that can profoundly affect toilet training include a desire for independence and self-mastery, the child's need to control some aspects of his environment, testing of limits and rules, his desire to win his parents' approval, fears associated with toilet use, and the desire to mimic or conform to other children's behavior. The best way to determine the emotional state your child is in, and how conducive this is to toilet training, is to observe both his general behavior and his responses to any suggestions about potty use. If he clearly enjoys sitting on his potty or talking about potty use, his urge toward self-mastery will probably support his training. If he resists the idea or cries when you mention the potty, he may be experiencing conflict and you will need to wait for a more opportune time. The desire to master one's own body and environment is a powerful desire common to all toddlers and preschoolers.

The onset of cries of "I can do it!" will let you know that your one- or two-year-old's urge toward independence is in full swing. On one hand, this type of ambition can inspire great toilet-training progress as your child tries to act like a big kid in every possible way. Periodically, however, his need to control his own body and environment may manifest itself in less-than-desirable ways. Your one-year-old may insist on running away and hiding each time he feels the urge to have a bowel movement-in an effort to prevent you from violating his fragile physical pride by picking him up and placing him on the potty. He may even get up off the potty and have an accident on the living room floor for the sheer satisfaction of making the decision where to urinate. At age two, he may yell "No!"

whenever you ask him if he needs to go, or delay going until it's too late and an accident occurs. The more attention you give such experiments-all normal attempts to test your rules and limits-the more he will repeat them. The best response is to clean up the mess, keep your comments minimal, downplay the incident, and wait for a later, more mature phase of independence to inspire him to show you what a "big boy" he can be. The desire to control his physical functions and his environment may increase during times of major change in the child's life. A child who feels disoriented by recent upsets (such as a move to a new home, a divorce, or the arrival of a new baby in the house) may seek to regain emotional balance by exerting tighter control over those aspects of life that are within reach. Inner stresses, such as fears resulting from a rapidly developing imagination, may also lead to resistant behavior that makes toilet training difficult. Older toddlers and preschoolers, who are physiologically able to delay bladder or bowel movements longer when desired, can deliberately withhold stool and become seriously constipated in response to emotional stress, parental pressure, or even reluctance to let go of what they experience as a part of their bodies.

Again, when confronted with such resistance it's best to talk with your child about what is upsetting him, do your best to allay his fears, and then back off for a while. With your help, your child will soon pass out of this emotional stage, and you can readdress toilet-training issues when he's better prepared to do so. Desire for Approval Two of the greatest tools parents can take advantage of during toilet training are their child's desire for approval and his urge to imitate others' behavior. The more smiles and words of parental praise he experienced, the more he desired, and except during the normal spurts of rebellion that occur throughout childhood, he will probably continue to make a great effort to please you. Throughout the toddler and preschool years, praising your child for any small step toward bathroom mastery will pave the way for faster, more positive training. If your child has not been successfully toilet-trained by age three and a half, his renewed desire to please can make adapting to potty use quite simple, for this is a time when many of his issues around independence will have been resolved.

In later chapters, we will discuss ways to tap into this desire to please through affirmation ("Look what a great job you did!") , sticker charts, and other forms of positive reinforcement. Social Awareness Social awareness-the observation of and desire to be like others-gradually expands throughout the toddler and preschool years, adding yet another motivator for your child to become fully toilet-trained. Teaching tot to play nice by Ann Douglas As printed in the Winter 2006 issue of Urbanbaby & Toddler magazine You've been looking forward to playgroup for days. Practically living for it during some of the rougher points in your week.

It's what motivated you to get your feet out from under the covers and on to the bedroom floor long this morning (that and the sing-song-y chanting of your toddler's voice from down the hall signaling that it's time to get up). But now that you've actually made your grand entrance at playgroup, the reality of doing anything with a toddler in tow has overtaken the fantasy once again. Before you can even get your toddler's jacket and boots off, he's managed to snatch a toy away from one of his playgroup pals and to tackle someone's baby brother. And if you happen to get the look from that mother whose toddler does no wrong you may feel like bailing from playgroup (Secretly, you wish her kid would bite someone just once, so that she'd lose that smug smile. Heck, you'd even offer up your own ankle for bait.) It's not all fun and games - well at least not at first It's easy to fall into the trap of expecting little kids to play in big kid ways.

Social skills take time to develop and toddlers and preschoolers are miles removed socially from older children. A toddler can be alone in a crowd. If you observe a group of very young toddlers playing in the same room, the first thing that might strike you about the situation is the fact that they may not be paying any attention to one another at all. They can be playing side by side, almost oblivious to one another. (That will come as they head into the preschool years, at which time they'll be ready for cooperative play.) Not only do they have the chance to work on their friendship skills: they also have the opportunity to practice a variety of other important skills and to help one another learn. Once preschoolers start to play with one another cooperatively (as opposed to engaging in parallel or side-by-side play - the typical form of play during the toddler years), they have the opportunity to learn how to problem solve as a group and to respect other people's thoughts and ideas - a whole new way of learning and thinking.

Adults have an important role to play in setting the stage for play. Toddlers and preschoolers are less likely to run into conflicts during playdates and at playgroup if they're well-rested and well-fed, feeling healthy, and if the environment is well designed for play (e.g., there are enough toys to keep everyone entertained and there's enough space for everyone to move around without bumping into one another). You'll find that it works well if you have a variety of activities planned so that you can vary between quieter activities (circle time or story time) and active play (outdoor play). Parents can help toddlers and preschoolers to manage their feelings of frustration. Dealing with other people can be frustrating, even when you're two or three. But that doesn't mean that you can haul off and clobber someone with a bucket of blocks. That's why it's so important to help your child master strategies for managing the powerful feelings that can arise when you're really, really mad at playgroup.

Playtime tips • Watch for signs that your toddler or preschooler is getting ready to lose his cool. When he's a toddler, your best strategy will be to intervene before he dive-bombs and chomps his teeth into another child. As he gets older, you can work in an element of learning: e.g., Teach him to recognize the powerful emotions he's feeling in himself (the physical "early warning signs" of anger, for example) and to deal with his feelings in a non-aggressive way (e.g., using his words, drawing a picture about how he is feeling, or coming to talk to you). • Avoid games that overemphasize competition or that tend to get young children all riled up. Very young children simply don't have the skills to manage the emotions that such games elicit. Stick to more cooperative forms of play instead. Don't forget to deal with your own feelings of frustration, too.

And don't sweat the fact that it always seems to be your kid who's tackling someone else for the toy fire truck. Everyone else's kid has done their time in the "but I don't want to share" trenches, whether those parents prepared to admit it or not. • Ask his playdate guest to bring along some toys to the playdate so that everyone is being asked to share. • Provide positive reinforcement when your child shares his toys. • Talk through any conflicts that arise if your child finds it impossible to share something. Ask your child to think about how he would feel if he was visiting his friend and his friend wouldn't share any toys. Playground etiquette every parent should know by Christy Laverty As printed in the Spring 2008 issue of Urbanbaby & Toddler magazine The sun is shining and the playground is calling. You load up the stroller and the kids. Drinks? Check. Extra diaper? Snacks?

Hat and sunscreen? And you're off. But hold on there. Playgrounds can be intimidating places. And if you think I mean for the kids, you would be wrong. Kids get it. Play wild and free-what kid doesn't know that?

(Well, actually I'm sure we all know or have seen a few of those.) But for parents, playgrounds can be places of long-lost memories, and unclear boundaries. Unfortunately the rules of the playground aren't posted. And we all know that isn't always the case. There is no doubt that playground play is a microcosm of the world. It is often where kids learn essential lifelong social skills. Melissa Leonard is a certified business etiquette and international protocol consultant.

She is also a mother of two. While she has worked with a number of Fortune 100 corporations, she also offers help and advice on etiquette for kids. Leonard has come up with a simple list of dos and don'ts to help parents, and kids, navigate the playground. DO keep an eye on your child: It is your responsibility as a parent/caregiver to watch for dangerous play, not sharing and hitting. DO share: The playground is a free for all in terms of pails, shovels, and chalk. Once an item arrives, it is fair game. Help to remind the child that their behaviour is dangerous and find the parent/caregiver to let them know.

DO pay attention: You don't want to be that parent who has the child who runs wild, grabs, throws sand and bullies. DON'T be a playground gossip: The playground can be like high school. Stay out of the gossip because you don't want to be labeled a trouble-maker. DON'T get mad when older kids hog the equipment: If it seems like older kids may knock over your child, go over and say, "We'll come back on the jungle gym when you are done playing," and take your child and engage him elsewhere. DON'T assume: There are three sides to the story-each child's version and then the truth. Don't assume your child did nothing wrong. Leonard says it is important to remember that kids often become territorial at playgrounds.

The fun and excitement of it all can cause simple manners to go out the window. Ann Hainsworth, mom to a busy one-year-old, remembers an incident involving her nephew at a neighbourhood playground. She says there was one child who wouldn't let her nephew, Kurtie, go past him on a bridge to the slide. Kurtie and Hainsworth were more than a little perturbed but Hainsworth used redirection to avoid a problem. "The parent of the other little boy, from what I could tell, was not prepared to discipline his child let alone introduce the concept of sharing." Hainsworth says it worked out well, but it was her first real lesson in what you deal with at a playground as a parent. On the other hand, parents/caregivers often see the playground as their break, a way for kids to keep busy while they catch up with other mothers and have some quiet time.

Leonard says you want to stay focused and remember, in regards to conflicts, it is not who is right, but what is right. One bad incident comes to mind for her. She says a four-year-old boy was playing in the playhouse and decided it would be okay to kick another boy in the mouth as he was coming up the ladder. "His tooth went through his lip, blood was everywhere and the mother of the kicker blamed the other boy for getting too close," says Van Ast-Hyland. According to Safe Kids Canada ( safekidscanada.ca ) an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 Canadian children need medical attention every year for playground injuries. Eighteen playground deaths have been reported since 1982. "The average lifetime of a park playground is about 15 years, but if you divide five or six playgrounds a year into 150 parks, it equals 25 to 30 years before the marching band comes to your local playground."

Palmer says there are issues of race and culture, sexual identity, and new definitions of family these days, and all of these factors come into play at playgrounds. He says ultimately it comes down to parents, guardians, and caregivers. "Parks and playgrounds see the most diverse use and diverse representation of our citizens as anything," sums up Palmer. "They are accessible, they are numerous and they are free. They are often taken for granted but are amongst the most effective use of public space. You don't need a permit. You don't have to have permission.

And they are just there." Let's face it: playgrounds let kids be kids. And give parents a sweet glimpse into their child's world and maybe even bring back fond memories of days gone by when they ran wild and carefree in the neighbourhood playground. Walk on the wild side: introduce your kids to nature by Daniela Ginta As printed in the Summer 2007 issue of Urbanbaby & Toddler magazine I remember hiking the Chief (near Squamish) when our family headcount was still down to two. Here are a few suggestions for helping your toddler become a nature lover early in life. Go for the Mountain Top Before you plan to set a new record of hiking the Grouse Grind with a toddler, go on easier hikes. Depending on your little tyke's endurance, start with short walks in parks such as Pacific Spirit Park in Vancouver, where you can find trails ranging in length and difficulty to fit everyone's liking and needs. Choose an easy trail and set off, encouraging your child to walk along, rather than climb on your back right away. Observe the forest together. There will be birds to hear; a little rustling here and there, signaling little forest animals scurrying away; and, of course, creeks with little creatures dancing in the water. Before you know it, you'll get to the end of the trail and your child might just say, "Again!"

Or he might ask you to carry him home, because the first hike was extremely tiring. Either way, celebrate his first hike with pride and joy. Prepare for this special first hike with a map for your child to carry and read. Show him where the trail starts and where it ends. Bike Along Toddlers love bikes, and even better, they love bike trips.

The question is: Where do you start? It depends on how comfortable your toddler is on a bike. Bike along the seawall in Stanley Park in Vancouver, or choose your own biking route. The goal is to make the biking trip fun and most importantly, to make the trip so much fun that your toddler will ask for seconds. For a special treat, pack your bikes and head over to one of the islands - there are beautiful and very peaceful biking routes, with plenty of natural beauty to enjoy and share with your child. Beachcombing Toddlers are fascinated by sand and water; you can use this innate passion to talk to your toddler about the creatures inhabiting the ocean, and how they make themselves known to us, by being washed ashore or by being caught by sea birds. Start your beachcombing adventure by packing picnic supplies and sand toys.

Make sure you bring a shovel so your toddler can dig for treasures. Draw a map of the beach section you set out to explore, and let your toddler decide where the resting stops are. Look for activities that are safest, keeping in mind that toddlers are unpredictable little human beings, which is why canoeing (and being on a boat in general) is not recommended until you know for sure that safety instructions are perfectly understood. Toddlers are enthusiastic though, which is bound to make most nature exploring trips enjoyable for both children and parents. However if your child is ready for training and is showing an interest, the chances are that it will go smoothly and you will wonder why you didn't do it sooner! One of the most important things to consider is the timing. Here are some indications that your child is ready to be toilet-trained:-

When your child can stay dry for an hour or two at a time and is sometimes dry after naps Understands the concepts involved e.g. Wet/dry , up/down, clean/dirty etc. This understanding helps them make sense of the process of toilet training. Has some awareness of body functions, lets you know in some way that they are having a bowel movement or urinating. The child who can tell when they are about to urinate is ready for training. Has some ability to communicate their needs and follow simple instructions. It helps if your child is able to do some simple dressing, e.g. pull up bottoms.

Curiosity about the bathroom habits of others. This can be the first step in toilet training - children love to be able to do what the grown-ups do. And Night Time ? When your child is occasionally waking up with dry nappies after their nights sleep. Frequently waking up dry from daytime naps. Beginning to be upset by nighttime wetting. Will get up during the night to go to the toilet.

Has the ability to stay dry for up to 4 hours during the day. There is not a set age to begin toilet training - rather it depends on the individual child. You need to take your child's lead in this and follow their cues. Some say that you should train during the summer months so the child can roam freely without nappies. However its more important that the timing is in tune with your child rather than waiting for the weather, after all in Ireland you could be waiting a while!! Tips for Toilet Training As you set out on this new adventure with your child here are some tips you may find useful:-

Follow your child's pace. Some children are trained with a fortnight but most take longer than that. If you think your child is finding the process of potty training too difficult and stressful then the best approach is to leave it for another few weeks/months and try again. If you put too much stress on the child they will find it very difficult to train and may be put off the whole exercise. Suggest but never force, you need your child's co-operation to train them and as any parent of a toddler knows they do not respond kindly to being forced into situations. Your approach needs to be low key and non-threatening. Avoid punishments - again it is vital that you have your child's co-operation and motivation when they are being trained.

It has to be a positive experience for them so punishments do not have a place in this process. Do not show disgust at faeces - young children can be fascinated about what comes out of their body. While you do not need to encourage this exploration you need to be careful not to show too much disgust as this might put the child off the whole process. Instill hygienic practices from day one - remember your young child will need help to wash hands properly. After every visit to the toilet or potty you should help your child wash their hands. If you insist on this practice at this early age it will become a habit for their lifetime. Give plenty of opportunities to go to the toilet.

In the first few weeks of toilet training you will need to remind your little one at frequent intervals to try the potty or toilet - as time goes on they will remember themselves. Use consistent vocabulary to describe toileting activities. Use the same words to describe what is happening when your child uses the toilet as when they are familiar with this vocabulary it will be easier for them to let you know when they need to use the toilet. Act promptly if asked for potty ! Praise is all important, try to concentrate on your child's achievements. As your child learns these new Skills, there will be a number of accidents. The best approach to these is to play them down and give most attention to your child's successes.

Below are some frequently asked questions by parents:- At what age should I start potty training? There is no specific age at which you should begin toilet training. It really depends on whether your child is ready or not. Check out Ready for Toilet Training. There is usually a window of opportunity when it comes to toilet training and starting to train too soon can put your child off the whole process and leaving it too late can mean you lose out on your child's motivation and cooperation when training. Are there things I can do beforehand to help prepare my child?

It is always a good idea to have a potty lying around so your child gets used to it. My son used it as a helmet for months before he started using it as a potty! It is also a good idea to allow your toddler to accompany you to the bathroom so they can see what you are doing. Let them help flush the toilet so they won't be scared of it when it comes to their turn to use it. Also encourage your child to help when you are dressing them so they are at the stage of being able to pull up their clothes after a nappy change etc. Be aware of the type of clothes you are buying for your child, make sure they are 'potty friendly', avoid buttons and zips as your small child will not be able to manage these just yet. Encourage your child to tell you when they have done a wee or poo in their nappy.

Also if you know they are doing something in their nappy talk to them about what they are doing - this will help to build their toileting vocabulary. The simple answer is when your child is ready. How long will it take? Just when you begin toilet training you are bound to hear of another child who was trained within days. Beware of expecting such quick results. Toilet training can take months and there will be many setbacks along the way. If you start with the expectation that your child will be fully toilet trained within a week you may be very disappointed.

On a poll conducted by RollerCoaster.ie we asked our visitors how long it took them to toilet train their child. It took 38% of parents over a month to toilet train their child, 26% of parents managed to toilet train their child in less than 1 month, 17% did so in 1 week while 19% did so in a few days. These results show that while some lucky parents manage to toilet train their child in the space of a few days, for the majority of us toilet training took much longer! For (almost ) 40% it took longer than 1 month to get it right. Should I train my son standing or sitting or both? It is best to train your son in a sitting position first, as this will give him the opportunity to urinate and defecate at the same time. Also trying to train small boys in both positions can be confusing and may lead to trouble.

If your son does not get enough time to sit on the toilet this could lead to constipation which can become a chronic problem very quickly. When your son is confident and secure in the sitting position you can move on to the standing position. Remember though there is no rush here. My friends disagree on the use of training pants, some say that I should use them others say no, what do you think? Some children do treat training pants just like nappies. However, training pants can be very useful, toddlers will see that you put them on like underpants. When you are going out with your toddler who is in the process of toilet training, training pants can be a great backup especially if you are unsure about the availability of toilets where you are going.

For the first few months always take a change of clothes with you on outings, as accidents will happen My child will happily use the potty for wees but will not do his poo in the potty or toilet, what can I do? You may have found it easy to train your child to do their wees in the potty or toilet but they still want to do their poos in their nappy. The best approach here is to be patient and not put your child under pressure. If you try to force your child to use the toilet or potty for their poos they may begin to stop themselves from doing them all together and this can easily lead to constipation. As you will already know its important to avoid power struggles with this age group - they invariable win! If you are finding that you and your child are struggling with this issue its best to take the pressure off and trust that your child will begin to use the toilet when they are ready.

Praise any attempts and don't let them see your disappointment or frustration. They are probably struggling just as much as you are and need your encouragement and patience. The best approach is to try and encourage your child to remain seated on the toilet or potty after doing their wee to see if anything else happens. Don't force the issue though. If they insist on using their nappy don't despair as they may not be ready yet to use the toilet. Let them use their nappy but maybe only in the bathroom and then flush the faeces down the toilet as usual and comment that they can use the toilet when they are ready. Giving you child a feeling of control over the process will help them.

I'm so angry with my child, they refuse to use the toilet of potty to do their poos when I know they are well capable of doing it properly. This situation can be very frustrating for parents and can lead to conflict. Be careful if you find yourself getting angry or scolding your child because they are refusing to use the toilet to do their poos. Toilet training requires the full cooperation of your child and if they feel that you are angry or disappointed with them they will lose their enthusiasm and motivation for toilet training. If your child feels they are being nagged over this they may decide to refuse to cooperate at all and begin 'withholding' their poos which can quickly lead to constipation which will further compound your situation. Patience and praise are needed here to help your child move on in their training. My child loves her potty but seems to be fearful when I put her on the toilet - how can I help her?

Small children can feel very insecure on the normal sized toilet seat. Special Insert Toilet seats especially for small children are a great idea; these can be purchased in nursery shops. A small plastic stool is also very useful as then your child will be able to get up on the toilet easier and climb down on their own. It can also be used to help your child reach the sink for hand washing, after each visit to the bathroom. If you begin before your child is ready, toilet training will be a struggle and if you leave it too late it might be difficult to get your child motivated. There are some signs and behaviours that indicate that your child is ready for toilet training, check out Ready for Toilet Training for a complete list. If you become involved in a power struggle over this issue you will probably not succeed.

A doctor's case for training later in childhood By Steve Hodges, M.D. with Suzanne Schlosberg | March 23, 2012 You've probably heard the arguments in favor of early toilet training. They train early in Europe! Toddlers are more compliant than three-year-olds! Diapers are bad for the environment! Perhaps you've even read scientific studies concluding that children who train later are more likely to end up having accidents.

As a pediatric urologist who specializes in toileting problems, I'll tell you this: Children under age 3 should not manage their own toileting habits any more than they should manage their college funds. Preschools that require 3-year-olds to be potty trained - like the one in Virginia that suspended 3 ½-year-old Zoe Rosso for excessive potty accidents - are harming kids. And infant toilet training, promoted in Mayim Bialik's new book Beyond the Sling , is just plain nuts - unless, like Bialik, you monitor your child 24/7, feed your child a high-fiber vegan diet, and home-school your child. Babies need to experience uninhibited voiding , or elimination, without the expectation of using the toilet at such an early age. It's not that young kids can't be potty trained. Sure they can. But knowing how to poop on the potty is not the same as responding to your body's urges in a judicious manner.

Let's fast-forward two or three years. That's when potty prodigies show up at my clinic - one of a handful specializing in dysfunctional voiding - with the sudden onset of pee and poop accidents, urinary tract infections (UTIs), urinary frequency, and/or bedwetting. "I don't get it," a mom will tell me. "I didn't push her - she basically trained herself." I believe these parents, but unfortunately it's typically the kids who trained earliest and most easily who develop the most serious problems. I see about 100 kids a week at my clinic, and about half are dysfunctional voiders; most of them trained before 3. To understand the risks of early training, it's important to know that virtually all toileting problems - pee and poop accidents, bedwetting, urinary frequency, and urinary tract infections - are related to chronically holding pee or poop or both.

Signs your kid is ready: • She/he can tell you she is peeing and pooping • She/he asks to use the toilet • She/he can dress and undress herself • Your child's poops are mushy (like sweet potatoes or hummus) Though some toddlers with older siblings insist that they want to use the potty, they don't understand what that means. Children - and I mean all children - don't like to interrupt their lives to use the bathroom.

Once kids learn to put off peeing and pooping, essentially the definition of toilet training, they tend to do so often and for as long as they can. Each time you squeeze your sphincter to prevent the release of pee, you create resistance in your bladder. What happens when muscles go up against resistance? Exactly what happens when you train your hamstrings at the gym: They get thicker and stronger. But unlike muscular hamstrings, a thicker bladder is a bad thing. It has a smaller capacity and its sensation mechanism goes awry. When a child habitually delays peeing, over months and years, his bladder wall becomes more muscular and eventually the bladder can get so strong and irritable that it empties without any input from the child.

Chronically holding poop, a problem exacerbated by our kids' low-fiber diets, compounds the damage. A mass of poop forms in the rectum, right behind the bladder, and can stretch the rectum from about 2 centimeters in diameter to 10 centimeters or more. There's only so much room in the pelvis, so the bladder gets squeezed out of the way and can't hold as much urine. What's more, the nerves controlling the bladder, which run between the bladder and the intestines, can get irritated when the intestines are enlarged, causing unexpected and unwanted bladder contractions - in other words, mad dashes to the toilet and accidents. Chronically holding pee and poop also causes urinary tract infections. The less often a child pees, the more opportunity for infection-causing bacteria to creep up to her bladder. And if this kid is also hauling around a hefty load of poop, she's harboring about a gazillion (to be precise) more times the bacteria than when her rectum has been emptied.

Since parents tend to believe potty problems are normal, many don't bother bringing their kids to the doctor. Even when they do see a physician, the cause of their children's toileting troubles often go unnoticed. That's because most parents, and even many pediatricians, equate constipation with infrequent pooping. In reality, many constipated kids poop regularly, even multiple times a day. Large poop masses in children typically go unnoticed because looser poop oozes by and finds a way out more easily than the hard stuff, giving the impression that the child has fully eliminated. This is what happened with Zoe Rosso, the girl who was suspended from preschool and who is now my patient. As it turned out, Zoe had a poop mass the size of a miniature Nerf football stuck in her rectum, which both her pediatrician and pediatric urology clinic missed because they failed to X-ray her.

Plenty of published research, including our clinic's 2012 study published in Urology , demonstrates that when you clear up clogged kids and prevent them from holding, the accidents, UTIs, and bedwetting episodes cease. These showed convincingly that children with wetting problems were severely constipated, despite showing few or no outward signs, and that treating constipation resolved the wetting and UTIs dramatically. The reason kids who train at age 2 have more of these problems than children who train later, in my opinion, is that they have spent more months or years deciding for themselves when they should pee or poop - before they're mature enough to understand the importance of eliminating as soon as they feel the urge. Parents often tell me their child has accidents because she has a "small bladder," as if an undersized bladder is something the child was born with. Do you know how often I see children who are still in diapers and have recurrent UTIs? Do you know how often I treat newly potty-trained children for recurrent UTIs? Every day.

These kids fill a quarter of my clinic. This is not a coincidence and demonstrates quite clearly that toilet training in very young children is harmful. There is no way that healthy, developmentally normal, un-constipated children who learn to use the potty at 3 ½ have a higher rate of chronic pee or poop accidents than children who train at 2 ½. Every year of constipation-free, uninhibited voiding - in other words, wearing diapers - leads to bladder growth; every year of holding shrinks the bladder and makes it more overactive. And consider this: Typical therapy for accidents involves giving kids laxatives and putting them on a pee schedule, taking the decision of when to eliminate out of their hands. Well, there's a major flaw in this research: The authors didn't check, via X-ray, to see if these kids were constipated at the time they started training. The records we keep at my clinic suggest that among late trainers, it's not the age of training, but rather unrecognized constipation that correlates with problems.

We have found that children who trained after age 3 and have toileting troubles either trained late because they were constipated (their parents had tried earlier but failed) or trained late and are constipated. So, if you are training your 2-year-old because the preschool you've chosen requires children to be potty trained by 3, I suggest you find another school. Sending an early-trained child to preschool only increases the risk of potty problems, particularly if these schools don't allow the safety net of a Pull-Up. Think about it: You're placing a 3-year-old in an unfamiliar environment where, for possibly the first time in her life, she has no family members around for half the day, and you're expecting her to interrupt her teacher during the story circle and announce that she needs to use the toilet or to climb out of the fort she's just built with her friends and make her way over to the potty. Whoever thought that was a good idea has surely never set foot in a pediatric urology clinic. Making matters worse, these kids are ill-equipped to deal with the sub-par restrooms and restrictive bathroom policies that may await them in elementary school and beyond. I have countless patients who have developed the capacity to hold their pee and poop from 7:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. - and have developed serious bladder problems and recurring urinary tract infections because of it.

Children who are newly potty trained need a lot of follow-up, no matter how well they are able to stay dry, and the earlier you train a child, the longer it's your responsibility to monitor the child's peeing and pooping habits closely. Children need reminders to use the toilet about every two hours. (And caretakers should never ask a child if he needs to go potty, because most kids will say no. It's your job to instruct the child when to go.) It's also important to glance at your child's poops whenever you have a chance (luckily, kids often forget to flush!) Look for poop that's thin and/or mushy, like mashed potatoes or hummus (it's the watery, diarrhea-like poops that signal a problem). Extra-large poops and thick, formed poops are signs of constipation.

You can also teach your child to check on his own poop and report its appearance to you. (Yeah, all this sounds gross, but these conversations are important for families to have, and lots of kids think talking about poop is fun stuff.) But don't get too fixated on your own potty liberation. You need to pay attention to your kids' pooping habits until you're absolutely positive they have it down. FORCING potty training early is bad. You should get rid of the diapers and keep him in underwear.

She loves looking at the chart, I kinda made my own version with it with drawing a smiley face for poop in potty and sad face for poop in pants, well she didn't want a sad face so it is really working! Long may it continue until she is back on track, I still have to watch her very closely for the signs as I know what she does so I tell her to go to the bathroom and she does...constipation was a big problem for us and ped recommended miralax which I hated as it made it the complete opposite and she couldn't control it, it was such a shame, I stopped it and then started using pedialax fiber gummies which work much better once you figure out how many they need, one of them a day helps her a lot and no problems like with the laxative powder, it really messed us up :( Anyhoo thanks again, love you guys' advice, it's been so helpful :) So my youngest boy got to be about 17 months old and saw his brothers announce they had to pee then go to the bathroom. So he'd announce, "I pee" then run to the toilet. Potty training is like learning to use utensils, we keep showing them and offering them and eventually they understand and get the skills to do so. When you do a dry undie check, use that as a reminder time to use the toilet. Only big kids play DS so if you stay dry and use potty all day, you can play after dinner.

Point is not to punish but make it clear that dirty undies don't get magically clean, it's their body and responsibility and that it's easier to use potty than go through all that. Don't over talk it or make poop or the potty your life or theirs. Poop is harder for children potty trained after age 2 and after 30 months, most kids have refusal to poop or holding or hiding. Some sort of issue with poop exists. The point is to make it impossible for them to hold it and for the poop to come out quick and easy so they are more willing to use the toilet than not. Make poop a good thing and don't use words like smelly, gross or yucky. I finally created a PDF file, made an Adobe account, made a FB page and pasted the link.

There are many differing opinions on potty training but what is known is that children trained later have more medical problems with their GI, kidney, bladder and bowel. They also bedwet longer, have more UTIs, higher instances of irritable bowel syndrome and constipation. Some get encropesis which is very difficult to deal with. Potty learning is no different really than teeth brushing, hand washing, bathing, weaning, sleep training,learning ABCs, etc., It is normal and the earlier, the more natural the transistion. This is the first generation where children are trained so late. Even Huggies and Pampers suggest potty training around 2 to 2 and half but society now waits until 40 months on average. Children and their capabilities haven't changed, diapers and parents have.Diapers are just easier, not better for our child or for the planet.Do you know it takes 100-200 years for ONE diaper to breakdown in our landfills?Our earth is littered with untreated waste with poopy and peepee diapers thrown into the garbage.

When poop goes into a toilet, it's treated by our sewer systems. Yes cloth is better but the amount of hot water, bleaches, detergents, hydro used to wash and dry them.not to mention time, can be lessened too by potty training. It's actually the time children are exercising their bladder and bowels the most. Info for potty training and please read message from GO above for more. Please read.Thanks. I just read through, watched the brief videos and got some ideas. I was very committed, patient and the master of inventive ideas. I did bare bum and then introduced panties fairly soon or you get kids that only stay dry or use potty bare and as soon as underwear go on, treat it like a diaper. I rewarded dry underwear with checks and also using potty. She put stickers on potty to decorate it. When out, we used small treats sometimes but not often nor for long.

She never asks or expects them so don't be afraid to use them at first. I used a doll and a hidden medicine syringe to have doll pee in potty and prunes for poop. She totally thought it was cool and funny. She loved watching the Alleke video and also empties, rinses and puts back her potty bowl (with my help I'm picky about germs). I think pullups are an expensive diaper and destroy potty training. Use cloth trainers or plastic undies over underwear for sanity in beginning on outings, naps and night. They're hidden in pullups and training pants if waterproof.

I used a $2 washable fabric marker and drew on the crotch of her undies and wrote her name. I showed her how it disappears when wet by dribbling some water on it. The ink disappears instantly. I told her if she pee and was wet, her name and picture would be bye bye. She loved seeing her name still there every potty break and at end of day. I created my own learning designs and cool alerts in one with cloth, a marker and urine. No expensive gimmicks for us thank you.

I used puppy training pads as cheap puddle pads or waterproof sheets on her bed with a towel or thin blanket tucked in over top. Easy cleanup and saves sheets. I find waterproof sheets sweaty and noisy. I used the puppy pads on stroller and car seat too. I kept an ikea $4 potty in the car. Put a plastic bag in the bowl of the potty (any potty) with paper towel in bottom. The paper absorbs all the liquid and you just tie the bag and toss.

Don't worry about how to clean potty on the road. A foldable travel potty seat, change of pants, underwear and socks when out. In beginning, take 2 changes. Never ask if they need to go but say "tell me when you need to use potty" or " it's time to use the potty." Give hi 5s to dad and have him also praise you for using the toilet. Make it fun so she/he wants to be part of it. Don't nag or give constant reminders or keep asking!

Don't take them constantly. Point is for them to learn their signals and learn potty habits. You can remind gently and say it's time to go when necessary (like outings) but don't annoy them by making every minute of the day about their poops and pees. Accidents are learning opportunities. Watch them like a hawk tho for signs they're "going". Children crave control and power. Potty training goes a lot easier if the child feels that they are part of it and have a choice.

Therefore, offering more choices during the day in all areas of life, will make them control the potty less. For example, which shirt do they want to wear,which snack do they want, milk or juice, which jacket, do they want to use little potty or big toilet, do they want to go first or mommy go first (if you go potty everytime with them,especially when out, they don't feel as singled out and it helps a lot), do they want to face in to the tank or out? Point is,if they feel they have some choice and a little control, they will rebel less. Take them to pick out their undies if possible and their rewards. iPhone has a potty time app that's a fun reminder. I used a dollar store timer that I had her set and when it dings, everyone goes potty. Worked for 2 days then she was annoyed by it.

However, we did great and advanced a lot those days. Have underwear be slightly large or they can't pull them up and down easily. The "right" size is ok once they're trained, til then, loose is better. Keep girls in dresses, skirts, nighties, long shirts at first for ease. Then pants with no buttons or zippers for both sexes. For cloth trainers, consider imse vimse, super undies, tinkle time trainers (my favorite), kidalog, Kushies (light weight), Potty Scotty or potty patty, blueberry, kissaluv, Motherease, and more... For day a lightweight trainer or underwear is best. For nights I'd suggest a pocket pullup trainer so you can adjust absorbency with inserts.

If you cloth diapered and have inserts/boosters, ladderhill designs, Rainshine designs and other WAHM on hyena cart or etsy will make the trainers to fit your inserts. They also will make soakers for you if you don't have them or you can buy them locally or online at a cloth diaper store. The hyena Cart and etsy trainer sellers also will make them to fit your child and you need to measure your child and pick designs, fabric and snaps, pullon, etc., totally customize your trainer. If you have poop issues, snaps can help a lot with mess. They can also make cloth diapers into trainers for you... You can buy your own pattern and sew your own trainers. There's YouTube videos too. I got 2 trainers with pockets, no snaps, pullon, PUL waterproof front, back and crotch but cotton sides.

I let DD look at pictures and puck her design. Of course princesses it was! With the cotton sides and made to fit trainers, they're more like underwear and trim and comfy. With a bamboo soaker in the pocket, they're good for night or in beginning training. Without the inserts, I can still use them as underwear especially as she loves the designs and there's cloth on them. You can find trainers on diaper swap sites, craigslist and eBay. Yes underwear is best but not always practical.

I suggest staying away from flannel or fleece inner linings on trainers. Stay with cotton or bamboo. Google cloth training pants. Diaperpins has reviews but there's lots online and even video reviews. Now you don't have to buy any books unless you want too. I did take books out of the library for DD to read on potty training. I did by Elmo's potty time movie on iTunes $4.99 and sesame street book Monsters in the Bathroom.

The book is amazing! Mote than PT! Elmo's Potty Book is probably the best picture potty book as it talks about using potty at school, at friends houses, before bed, etc., Others are good to but I find some still talk about diapers at naps and bedtime or aren't clear enough on the potty training message. Bye Bye Diapers by SesameStreet is Good. That is my personal opinion and experience from others but your choice. I used the Internet and YouTube for rest for free. Don't be scared to ask for help.

Be patient and remember, every child is different and there's no magic. In the early days, crying, whining, being unable to pee on command, holding poop, jumping up too fast, thousand accidents, asking for a diaper, etc., are all normal. It doesn't mean they aren't ready, it just means this is new and they are testing you and their boundaries. Prepare for training by reading some books with them and talking about it. Have them sit at times they are most likely to go for a bit but not too long. Part time training and going back and forth can really send a mixed message and cause resistance. Once you start, the point is to move forward and be confident.

Potty success is determined by parents/caregivers and our attitudes and commitment. Children trust us so if we show fear, hesitancy or disbelief in their abilities,they feed off it and won't progress. The toilet is normal and less scary if you think about it or strange than carseats, exersaucers, strollers, swings, cribs, intellitainers, high chairs, tricycles and everything else we put our children into. We wrestle children into diapers for years day in and day out. It is part of their routine and they are trained to them and immune to the workings of their bodies and desensitized to their signals, urges and poop and pee. After years of pooping themselves, why would they mind it? They also become lazy and stubborn.They want control and to have things easy where they lay arounnd or play and poop and mommy cleans it.

I recently posted a thread called "if you think we are crazy to suggest Pt" and there are many many 5 year olds not potty trained nowadays and missing school as a result. That isn't normal. Barring medical or developmental delays, children can be potty trained and should be, much earlier. I know many moms don't know this or are given misinformation by others or their doctors who don't study potty learning in med school nor train kids themselves.
